THTR 1.title: Play Analysis
THTR 1.description: Provides the theater artist with practical tools for text analysis. Studying five major works ranging from Shakespeare to a living playwright, the course examines such concepts as language, style, period, character, themes, and structure.

THTR 2A.title: Performance in Global Contexts: Africa and the Caribbean
THTR 2A.description: Introduction to local performance traditions in Africa and the Caribbean, such as storytelling, ritual, and Carnival.  The course also examines how African and Caribbean playwrights put those traditions to social and political uses by incorporating them into post-colonial plays.

THTR 2B.title: Performance in Global Contexts: ASIA
THTR 2B.description: Introduction to pan-Asian performance traditions (theater, dance, performance art, popular culture) in various national genres such as Beijing opera, Chinese spoken drama, Taiwanese heavy metal, Indian and Korean dance, Japanese Noh, Bunraku, Anime, and Indonesian mask and puppet theater.

THTR 2C.title: Performance in Global Contexts: EUROPE
THTR 2C.description: Introduction to theater and performance practice and traditions in Europe. Topics will include ritual, the rise of a public theater, the political uses of theater, the development of festival theater, and the uses of performance in non-theatrical contexts.

THTR 2D.title: Performance in Global Contexts: LATIN AMERICA
THTR 2D.description: An introduction to theater and performance in Latin America.

THTR 5.title: Introduction To Acting
THTR 5.description: An introduction for majors and nonmajors to the multiple problems of the actor's art and craft.

THTR 9.title: Introduction to Dramatic Writing
THTR 9.description: An intensive introduction to playwriting for beginning dramatists. Students will read and analyze the structure of plays, write and stage their own short plays, and gain experience acting in and directing each other's work. Homework for the course includes a series of written and performance-based assignments.

THTR 10A.title: Movement For The Stage
THTR 10A.comments: Students must be concurrently enrolled in Theater 15A. Restricted to BFA Acting students.
THTR 10A.description: Intense physical training designed to produce a neutral, dynamic, and expressive bodily instrument.

THTR 10B.title: Movement For The Stage
THTR 10B.comments: Students must be concurrently enrolled in THTR 15B. Restricted to BFA Acting students.
THTR 10B.description: Intense physical training designed to produce a neutral, dynamic, and expressive bodily instrument.

THTR 10C.title: Movement For The Stage
THTR 10C.comments: Can be repeated once for credit. Restricted to BFA Acting students.
THTR 10C.description: Intense physical training designed to produce a neutral, dynamic, and expressive bodily instrument.

THTR 11A.title: Voice Laboratory
THTR 11A.comments: Can be repeated once for credit. Restricted to BFA Acting students.
THTR 11A.description: A fundamental approach to voice for the actor with emphasis on vocal production, articulation, and quality; plus physical relaxation techniques.

THTR 11B.title: Voice Laboratory
THTR 11B.comments: Can be repeated once for credit. Restricted to BFA Acting students.
THTR 11B.description: A fundamental approach to voice for the actor with emphasis on vocal production, articulation, and quality; plus physical relaxation techniques.

THTR 11C.title: Voice Laboratory
THTR 11C.comments: Can be repeated once for credit. Restricted to BFA Acting students.
THTR 11C.description: A fundamental approach to voice for the actor with emphasis on vocal production, articulation, and quality; plus physical relaxation techniques.

THTR 15A.title: Fundamentals of Acting
THTR 15A.comments: Restricted to BFA Acting students. Can be repeated once for credit.
THTR 15A.description: Development of the intermediate actor's foundational work in improvisation, technique, scene study, textual analysis, and characterization while exploring creative capacity.

THTR 15B.title: Fundamentals of Acting
THTR 15B.comments: Restricted to BFA Acting students. Can be repeated once for credit.
THTR 15B.description: Development of the intermediate actor's foundational work in improvisation, technique, scene study, textual analysis, and characterization while exploring creative capacity.

THTR 15C.title: Fundamentals of Acting
THTR 15C.comments: Restricted to BFA Acting students. Can be repeated once for credit.
THTR 15C.description: Development of the intermediate actor's foundational work in improvisation, technique, scene study, textual analysis, and characterization while exploring creative capacity.

THTR 19.title: Design Fundamentals for Dance and Theater
THTR 19.comments:
Misc: Not open for credit to students who have completed Theater W 19.
Repeat Comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Theater W 19.
THTR 19.description: Lectures, demonstrations and projects to provide an understanding of the stage design process for theater and dance. Study of the elements, principles, terminology, and basic techniques. Exploration of the communicative and collaborative process between designer and choreographer/director. Concentration in scenic, costume, and lighting design.

THTR 22.title: Scenic Design
THTR 22.comments: Open to non-majors. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units with instructor consent.
THTR 22.description: Projects in the interpretation of plays through scenic elements with concentration on the design process and the dramatic use of space. Drafting projects including floor plans, elevations and basic perspective drawing.

THTR 23.title: Stage Lighting Design
THTR 23.comments: Open to non-majors. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units with instructor consent.
THTR 23.description: Lecture-demonstration in instrumentation, color in light, control equipment, and basic lighting design theories. Technical drawing including light plots, scheduling and organization for lighting design. Some practical application through laboratory and studio exercise.

THTR 23D.title: Dance Lighting Design
THTR 23D.description: Lecture-demonstration in instrumentation, color in light, control equipment, and basic lighting theories. practical application through laboratory assignments and studio productions.

THTR 25.title: Costume Design
THTR 25.comments: Open to non-majors. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units with instructor consent.
THTR 25.description: Exploration of basic elements and principles of theatre costume design. Projects in the interpretation of plays through costume elements with concentration on the design process. Emphasis on figure drawing.

THTR 27A.title: Theater Graphics and Figure Drawing
THTR 27A.description: Introduction to sketching and drawing styles for the theater designer. Includes light and shade, perspective, and line drawing. Focus on drawing the human form, rendering of fabric, texture and movement.

THTR 29A.title: Scenic Practicum
THTR 29A.description: Empirical understanding of methods of assembly and materials for stage scenery. Shop organization and operation are experienced during the construction process.

THTR 29B.title: Lighting Practicum
THTR 29B.description: Empirical understanding of optical properties of lightin units, available hanging positions and apparatus, lighting control, electrical safety and stage crew organization.

THTR 29C.title: Costume Practicum
THTR 29C.description: Empirical understanding of methods of assembly and materials for stage dress. Costume shop organization and operation are experienced during the construction process.

THTR 29D.title: Run Crew Practicum
THTR 29D.description: Empirical understanding of backstage organization and operation during live performance.

THTR 31A.title: Costume Construction
THTR 31A.description: Introduction to materials and construction techniques used in the production of theatrical costumes.

THTR 40.title: Theater Games
THTR 40.description: Using theater games, improvisation and storytelling, this course expands the imagination and frees the instincts of the actor. Exercises reflect the work of improvisation icons such as Viola Spolin, Augusto Boal, and Paul Sills. Students also explore techniques for sharing/teaching these games in community settings such as schools, senior citizen centers, etc. Prerequisite: Theater 5 or Instructor's Approval. Highly recommended for students focusing on Theater and Community.

THTR 42. I.V.title: I.V. Live
THTR 42. I.V.comments: A maximum of 16 units of Theater 42 and 142 combined may be accepted for credit in the major.
THTR 42. I.V.description: This course produces a weekly performance series in Isla Vista.  Students get first-hand experience in the rigors of theatrical production, as they learn to execute all logistical, technical, and promotional details. The course is affiliated with Isla Vista Arts.

THTR 43.title: The People's Voice
THTR 43.comments: Open to non-majors. Concurrently offered with THTR 143. A maximum of 8 units of Theater 43 and 143 combined may be accepted for credit in the major.
THTR 43.description: Students and teens from the community collaborate in writing, crafting, and performing an epic myth through the lens of their personal stories.

THTR 49.title: Theater Workshop
THTR 49.comments: A maximum of 25 units of Theater 49 and 149 combined may be accepted for credit in the major.
THTR 49.description: Projects in costume, scenery, lighting, acting, directing.

THTR 94.title: Group Studies For Lower-Division Students
THTR 94.comments: May be repeated for up to 8 units of credit.
THTR 94.description: Special opportunities for study, research, and project preparation.

THTR 95.title: Introduction to Stage Management
THTR 95.description: Foundational course exploring the full range of duties and responsibilities of a stage manager, a vital role for all theatrical and dance productions.

THTR 104A.title: Playwriting Workshop
THTR 104A.comments:
May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units. Same course as ENGL 106A.
Repeat Comments: This course is a legal repeat of ENGL 106A.
THTR 104A.description: An exploration of the essential components of playwriting. Exercises focus on writing dialogue, monologue, creating three-dimensional characters, building effective story structures, and developing action through language and stage images. A series of written assignments.

THTR 104B.title: Advanced Playwriting Workshop
THTR 104B.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units. Same course as English 106B.
THTR 104B.description: A continued exploration of the essential components of playwriting. Writing exercises in dialogue, monologue, character, story structure, action and stage images. Students focus on developing their individual writing voice. A series of written assignments.

THTR 104C.title: Collaboration & Ensemble Devising
THTR 104C.comments: May be repeated for credit up to 8 units.
THTR 104C.description: Open to playwrights, dancers, directors, actors, and designers. A series of written and ensemble performance-based assignments in which small groups explore different ways of generating and staging new material.

THTR 104D.title: New Works Lab
THTR 104D.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.
THTR 104D.description: An exploration of story structures and technique through rigorous workshopping and on-its-feet development, and a series of written and performance-based assignments.

THTR 104E.title: Generating New Material (Solo Performance)
THTR 104E.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.
THTR 104E.description: Focuses on the development of solo performance pieces through the theatrical exploration of objects and how they can be used to construct visual metaphors. Emphasis is on physical forms of storytelling and methods of building a dramatic work moment by moment through research and generative writing. A series of written and performance-  based assignments. Open to playwrights, designers, dancers, actors, and directors.

THTR 110A.title: Advanced Movement for the Stage
THTR 110A.prereq_description: Theater 10C; concurrent enrollment in Theater 151A. Consent of instructor.
THTR 110A.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 4 units. Restricted to BFA Acting students.
THTR 110A.description: A continuation of the Theater 10 series with increased focus on physical characterization and technical skills.

THTR 110B.title: Advanced Movement For The Stage
THTR 110B.prereq_description: Concurrent enrollment in Theater 151B. Consent of instructor.
THTR 110B.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 4 units. Restricted to BFA Acting students.
THTR 110B.description: A continuation of the Theater 10 series with increased focus on physical characterization and technical skills.

THTR 110C.title: Advanced Movement For The Stage
THTR 110C.prereq_description: Concurrent enrollment in Theater 151C. Consent of instructor.
THTR 110C.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 4 units. Restricted to BFA Acting students.
THTR 110C.description: A continuation of the Theater 10 series with increased focus on physical characterization and technical skills.

THTR 110D.title: Advanced Performance Projects
THTR 110D.description: Advanced studio projects utilizing the actor's physical and vocal skills to develop original theater.

THTR 110E.title: Stage Combat for Actors
THTR 110E.description: A practical exploration of the basic techniques and methods required to create the illusion of violence on stage. Hand to hand, quarterstaff, broadsword, rapier and dagger and other historical weapon systems will be integrated with foundational acting and storytelling principles. A materials fee will be required for use of theatrical weapons.
THTR 110E.recommended_prep: Prior movement, dance or martial art training.

THTR 111A.title: Advanced Voice Laboratory
THTR 111A.description: Advanced problems in voice for the actor with continued emphasis on craft, plus the creative and expressive uses of the voice with the body.

THTR 111B.title: Advanced Voice Laboratory
THTR 111B.description: Advanced problems in voice for the actor with continued emphasis on craft, plus the creative and expressive uses of the voice with the body.

THTR 111C.title: Advanced Voice Laboratory
THTR 111C.description: Advanced problems in voice for the actor with continued emphasis on craft, plus the creative and expressive uses of the voice with the body.

THTR 112.title: Senior Voice Laboratory
THTR 112.comments: Restricted to BFA Acting students. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 4 units.
THTR 112.description: Seminar in advanced voice work for senior students in B.F.A.-Acting program. Concentration on projects to find a personal voice in the theatre.

THTR 122.title: Advanced Scenic Design
THTR 122.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 7 units with instructor consent.
THTR 122.description: Concentration on various set design problems including period and style. Includes drawing, drafting of plans and elevations and rendering techniques.

THTR 123.title: Advanced Stage Lighting Design
THTR 123.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 7 units with instructor consent.
THTR 123.description: Lecture-demonstration of controllable properties and functions of light. Includes technical drawing: light plots, scheduling and organization for lighting design, drawing using light and shadow, perspective drawing. Practical application through studio exercise.

THTR 124.title: Design Portfolio
THTR 124.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 7 units with instructor consent.
THTR 124.description: Exploration of advanced design projects with concentration on individual portfolios.

THTR 125.title: Advanced Costume Design
THTR 125.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 7 units.
THTR 125.description: Execution of theoretical costume design projects. Concentration on various costume design problems including period, style, rendering techniques, and figure drawing.

THTR 127.title: Theatre Rendering Techniques
THTR 127.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 6 units with instructor consent.
THTR 127.description: Advanced theatre rendering techniques for the theatre designer. Continued development in drawing and use of different mediums. Concentration on rendering light, shadow, and texture.

THTR 132.title: History of Decorative Styles
THTR 132.description: A survey of the evolution of design styles and production trends in western theater, emphasizing the history of design and designers, including a study of both interior and exterior decoration with concentration on furnishing, accessories and the changing patterns of culture.

THTR 134P.title: Puppet Design and Construction
THTR 134P.description: Explores the history of various puppet styles and will focus on the design and creation of three iconic puppet forms: Thai shadow puppets (Nang yai), rod puppets (Bunraku), and marionettes. Students will learn both the mechanical aspects and the artistic design elements of puppet creation by creating one of each of these three styles.

THTR 140A.title: Advanced Acting Workshop I
THTR 140A.description: Advanced exploration, performances, and criticism of scenes from a broad range of dramatic scripts with focus on the actor's perspective.

THTR 140B.title: Advanced Acting Workshop II
THTR 140B.description: Further exploration of performances and criticism of scenes from a broad range of dramatic scripts with focus on the actor's perspective.

THTR 141.title: Shakespeare Basics
THTR 141.description: Theater 141, Shakespeare Basics, provides the tools for analyzing and acting Shakespearean text. This is an actor's approach. Through the study of sense, scansion/rhythm, phrasing, speech units, word structure, figures of speech, key words, imagery, reception/impact, physical action, inner and outer focal points the student lays the groundwork for interpreting and embodying Shakespeare characters. While this course serves as a basic entry to Shakespeare, the student is expected to have some experience or training as an actor and familiar with the terms objective, given circumstances, intention, personalization, and subtext.

THTR 142.title: I.V. Live
THTR 142.comments: A maximum of 16 units of Theater 42 and 142 combined may be accepted for credit in the major.
THTR 142.description: This course produces a weekly performance series in Isla Vista. Students get first-hand experience in the rigors of theatrical production, as they learn to execute all logistical, technical and promotional details. The course is affiliated with Isla Vista Arts.

THTR 143.title: The People's Voice
THTR 143.comments: Open to non-majors. Concurrently offered with Thtr 43. A maximum of 8 unitsof Theater 43 and 143 combined may be accepted for credit in the major.
THTR 143.description: Students and teens from the community collaborate in writing, crafting, and performing an epic myth through the lens of their personal stories.

THTR 144A.title: Shakespeare Production
THTR 144A.comments: Concurrently offered. Quarters usually offered: Summer. A 2-quarter, in-progress sequence with both grades given upon completion of Theater 144B.
THTR 144A.description: Students study, rehearse and produce one of Shakespeare's plays. The class culminates with performances that are open to the public during the final week. Students can participate as actors, assistant directors, designers or stage managers.

THTR 144B.title: Shakespeare Production
THTR 144B.comments: Concurrently offered. Quarters usually offered: Summer. A 2-quarter, in-progress sequence with both grades given upon completion of Theater 144B.
THTR 144B.description: Students study, rehearse and produce one of Shakespeare's plays. The class culminates with performances that are open to the public during the final week. Students can participate as actors, assistant directors, designers or stage managers.

THTR 145.title: Oregon Shakespeare Festival Tour
THTR 145.comments: There is a separate materials fee for this course that includes admission to all events and lodging in Oregon. Travel and meals are not included and are the responsibility of each student.
THTR 145.description: Students study one or more plays being performed at the Oregon Shakespeare Festival. While in Ashland, students attend 7-8 performances, take a backstage tour and participate in workshops and lectures led by members of the company.

THTR 146.title: Launch Pad: New Plays in Process
THTR 146.description: Working with the artistic director of LAUNCH PAD and 3 professional playwrights, this 3-week intensive course workshops a new play every week. Student actors, directors, designers, dramaturgs, playwrights, and stage managers learn the vital skills of working on new plays in the earliest stages of their development. The workshop culminates in an invited public reading at the end of each week. Over the 3 weeks, participants have the opportunity to take on different functions in the process.

THTR 149.title: Theatre Workshop
THTR 149.comments: A maximum of 25 units of Theater 49 and 149 combined may be accepted for credit in the major.
THTR 149.description: Projects in costume, scenery, lighting, acting, directing.

THTR 151A.title: Advanced Acting
THTR 151A.prereq_description: Theater 15C and 188S; concurrent enrollment in Theater 110A and 111A. Consent of instructor.
THTR 151A.comments: Can be repeated once for credit. Restricted to BFA Acting students.
THTR 151A.description: Scene work and exercises exploring various acting styles which may include Shakespeare, Boal, Artaud, Greek, period comedy and farce, and Absurd.

THTR 151B.title: Advanced Acting
THTR 151B.prereq_description: Theater 15C and 188S; concurrent enrollment in Theater 110B and 111B. Consent of instructor.
THTR 151B.comments: May be repeated once for credit by recommendation of instructor. Restrictedto BFA Acting students.
THTR 151B.description: Scene work and exercises exploring various acting styles which may include Shakespeare, Boal, Artaud, Greek, period comedy and farce, and Absurd.

THTR 151C.title: Advanced Acting
THTR 151C.prereq_description: Theater 15C and 188S; concurrent enrollment in Theater 110C and 111C. Consent of instructor.
THTR 151C.comments: May be repeated once for credit by recommendation of instructor. Restrictedto BFA Acting students.

THTR 151D.title: Advanced Acting: Modern Trends
THTR 151D.description: Study and performance of contemporary acting developments.

THTR 151F.title: Senior Auditions
THTR 151F.description: Preparation and study of material and techniques for professional and graduate school audition.

THTR 151G.title: Alternate Acting Styles
THTR 151G.description: Continued work in performance styles and other skills.

THTR 152A.title: Introduction to Stage Directing
THTR 152A.comments:
Quarters usually offered: Fall. This course is not open to students who have taken Theater 152.
Repeat Comments: This course is not open to students who have taken THTR 152.
THTR 152A.description: Basic principles and practice of directing. Lectures, demonstrations, and projects to give the nonspecialist and potential directing emphasis student a general idea of the directorial process.

THTR 152C.title: Advanced Directing
THTR 152C.description: Advanced directing techniques and scene work, including departures from realism. Students also learn about collaboration with designers.

THTR 152D.title: Directorial Production
THTR 152D.description: Full directorial responsibility for the mounting of a one-act play.

THTR 152E.title: Projects in Directing
THTR 152E.description: Full directorial responsibility for the mounting of a second one-act play or other special project.

THTR 153P.title: Projects in Design and Production
THTR 153P.description: Special projects in each area of concentration.

THTR 160C.title: Applied Theater/The Artist as Activist - Basics
THTR 160C.description: The Artist as Activist Basics introduces the student to the fundamentals of Applied Theater through examination of theory, history and imagining as a preparation for application and fieldwork. The course prepares the student to implement a project in the community. The project can be teaching or performance based. In addition to developing as researchers and theater activists, students will learn about the producing, promotional and ethical dimensions of self-starting a Theater & Community initiative.
THTR 160C.recommended_prep: Theater 9, 19, 180G; one course from 180C, 180D, 180E, or 180F and 12 unitsfrom three of the following courses: Theater 142, 143, 144A-B, 152A, 187MU,187TB, 195.

THTR 160D.title: Applied Theater/The Artist as Activist - Application
THTR 160D.description: The Artist as Activist Application is the follow-up course to The Artist as Activist Basics. The application course is individualized instruction with a fieldwork component. The student will work closely under the supervision of faculty on a community project. This project can be teaching or performance based. The Artist as Activist Application will only be offered to those students who show potential to work constructively in the community.

THTR 180A.description: History of the American drama and theater from early years to 1940. Important plays, performers, institutions, and styles of production are given selective attention.

THTR 180B.title: American Drama 1940 to Present
THTR 180B.description: History of the American drama and theater from 1940 to the present. Important plays, performers, institutions, and styles of production are given selective attention.

THTR 180C.title: Contemporary American Drama and Theater
THTR 180C.description: Close study of major playwrights, directors, solo performance artists, and other artists working in the contemporary American theater, mainstream and avant-garde. Writing assignments focus on developing critical arguments about new work.

THTR 180D.title: Latin American Theater and Performance
THTR 180D.description: Survey of Hispanic-American drama and theory including authors like Carballido, Gambaro, Marques, Triana, Valdez, and others.

THTR 180E.title: Culture Clash: Studies in U.S. Latino Theater
THTR 180E.description: A survey, in English, of the dramatic literature of U.S. Latinos from 1965 to the present. Includes history and criticism of the theater of Chicano, Puerto Rican, Cuban, and other Americans of Hispanic origin in the U.S.

THTR 180F.title: Asian American Theater
THTR 180F.comments:
Same course as AS AM 125.
Repeat Comments: This course is a legal repeat of AS AM 125.
THTR 180F.description: Overview of Asian American theater and its political and artistic achievements, from foundational Asian American theater companies and playwrights to contemporary performance artists. Issues addressed include race and ethnicity, gender and sexuality, and intergenerational conflict.

THTR 180G.title: Race, Gender, and Performance
THTR 180G.description: Comparative analysis of contemporary American plays and performances by artists of diverse gender, sexual, ethnic, and racial backgrounds. Students learn to perceive and critically respond to race and gender issues in plays and the theatrical production.

THTR 181AAZZ.title: National Studies in European Theater and Drama
THTR 181AAZZ.comments: May be repeated for credit provided letter designations are different.
THTR 181AAZZ.description: Special topics in European theater and drama.

THTR 182AAZZ.title: Transnational Studies in European Theater and Drama
THTR 182AAZZ.comments: May be repeated for credit provided letter designations are different.
THTR 182AAZZ.description: Special topics in transnational studies in European theater and drama.

THTR 183AAZZ.title: Asian Theater and Performance
THTR 183AAZZ.comments: May be repeated for credit provided letter designations are different.
THTR 183AAZZ.description: Special topics in Asian theater and performance.

THTR 184AAZZ.title: African and Caribbean Performance
THTR 184AAZZ.comments: May be repeated for credit provided letter designations are different.
THTR 184AAZZ.description: Special topics in African and Caribbean performance.

THTR 185AAZZ.title: Cross-Cultural Studies in Theater and Drama
THTR 185AAZZ.comments: May be repeated for credit provided letter designations are different.
THTR 185AAZZ.description: Special topics in cross-cultural studies in theater and drama.

THTR 187AAZZ.title: Performance Studies
THTR 187AAZZ.comments: May be repeated for credit provided letter designations are different.

THTR 188AAZZ.title: History of Performance
THTR 188AAZZ.comments: May be repeated for credit provided letter designations are different.
THTR 188AAZZ.description: Special topics in the history of performance.

THTR 190.title: Production Administration
THTR 190.comments: May be repeated for up to six units of credit.
THTR 190.description: Workshop for advanced students functioning as assistants to directors, designers, and technical directors. portfolio, promptbook, or paper required.

THTR 192.title: Upper-Division Seminar
THTR 192.description: A seminar course for upper-division students in the Theater Studies emphases. Topics are selected according to the interests of the students.

THTR 193H.title: Senior Honors Project
THTR 193H.comments: Students must have a 3.0 university grade-point average; 3.4 departmental grade-point average, unless exempt by petition; faculty nomination. This course is for students who will complete their projects in one quarter. A final grade will be assigned upon completion.
THTR 193H.description: Senior honors project. Advanced thesis project in either academic researchor creative activity, supervised by a faculty adviser. Students successfully completing the project, as evalutated by a three-person committee, will graduate with distinction in the major.

THTR 193HA.title: Senior Honors Project
THTR 193HA.comments: Students must have 3.0 university GPA; 3.4 depart. GPA; faculty nomination.4 to 8 units required in honors sequence; minimum of 2 units per quarter. Course is the 1st in sequence for students who will complete their projectsin either 2 or 3 quarters. An "in-progress" grade will be assigned; studentsmay then enroll in either DA 193HB or 193HC.
THTR 193HA.description: Senior honors project. Advanced thesis project in either academic research or creative activity, supervised by a faculty advisor. Students successfully completing the project, as evaluated by a three-person committee, will graduate with distinction in the major.

THTR 193HB.title: Senior Honors Project
THTR 193HB.comments: Four to eight units required in the honors sequence; minimum two units per quarter. This course is the second in the sequence for students who will complete their projects in three quarters. An "in-progress" grade will be assigned; students will then enroll in Dramatic Art 193HC.
THTR 193HB.description: Senior honors project. Advanced thesis project in either academic research or creative activity, supervised by a faculty advisor. Students successfully completing the project, as evaluated by a three-person committee, will graduate with distinction in the major.

THTR 193HC.title: Senior Honors Project
THTR 193HC.comments: Four to eight units required in the honors sequence; minimum two units per quarter. This course is the final in the two or three quarter sequence. A final grade will be assigned upon completion.
THTR 193HC.description: Senior honors project. Advanced thesis project in either academic research or creative activity, supervised by a faculty advisor. Students successfully completing the project, as evaluated by a three-person committee, will graduate with distinction in the major.

THTR 194A.title: Group Studies in Acting and Directing
THTR 194A.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 16 units.
THTR 194A.description: Intensive study, research, and project preparation in acting and directing.

THTR 194D.title: Group Studies in Design
THTR 194D.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 16 units.
THTR 194D.description: Intensive study, research, and project preparation in theatrical design.

THTR 194L.title: Group Studies in Literature
THTR 194L.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 16 units.
THTR 194L.description: Intensive study, research, and project preparation in dramatic literature.

THTR 194T.title: Group Studies in Theatre
THTR 194T.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 16 units.
THTR 194T.description: Intensive study, research, and project preparation in theatre.

THTR 195.title: Principles of Stage Management
THTR 195.description: Upper division course that builds upon the foundational information of THTR 95, providing a greater depth and breadth of exploration into the duties of the stage manager from pre-production through strike. Topics include communication, organizational skills, rehearsal procedures, and performance responsibilities. Greater stage management practical experience gained through in-class exercises and outside assignments.

THTR 195P.title: Stage Management Practicum
THTR 195P.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 16 units.
THTR 195P.description: Production oriented course allowing student practical experience in stage management training. Student will serve as assistant stage manager or stagemanager for a main stage or student directed departmental production.

THTR 196.title: Dance Production
THTR 196.prereq_description: Theater 19; 22 or 123 or 125; upper-division standing; consent of
THTR 196.comments:
May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 16 units, only 8 units may be applied toward the major.
Repeat Comments: (Legal repeat of DA 186.
THTR 196.description: Exploration of the process of collaboration between dance choreographers and theater designers in the development of designs for dance productions. Final project is a public performance of the choreographers' and designer' work.

THTR 199.title: Independent Studies in Theater
THTR 199.prereq_description: Consent of instructor; completion of 2 upper-division courses in
THTR 199.comments: Students must have a minimum 3.0 GPA for the preceding 3 quarters and arelimited to 5 units per quarter and 30 units total in all 98/99/198/199/199AA-ZZ courses combined.

THTR 199RA.title: Independent Research Assistance in Theater
THTR 199RA.prereq_description: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in
THTR 199RA.comments: Students must have a minimum 3.0 GPA for the preceding 3 quarters and arelimited to 5 units per quarter and 30 units total in all 98/99/198/199/199AA-ZZ courses.
THTR 199RA.description: Independent research assistance in theater. Supervised assistance in faculty research project.

THTR 210AAZZ.title: Research Methods in Theater, Dance and Performance Studies
THTR 210AAZZ.description: Introduction to select methods for conducting advanced research in theatre, drama, and performance. Students will read exemplary monographs and statements of method from leading scholars in the field. They will then practically apply those methods to an original, ongoing research project that will culminate in a substantive seminar paper.

THTR 210A.title: Research Methods: Ethnography and Performance
THTR 210A.description: Introduction to select methods for conducting advanced research in theatre, drama, and performance. The methodological focus, which varies according to instructor, may include ethnography, historiography, dramatic criticism, phenomenology, or audience reception, among others. Students will read exemplary monographs and statements of method from leading scholars in the field.  They will then practically apply those methods to an original, ongoing research project that will culminate in a substantive seminar paper.

THTR 211AAZZ.title: Theories for Performance, Theater, and Dance Research
THTR 211AAZZ.description: Introduction to key theories and conceptual frameworks for conduction advanced research in theater, dance, and performance studies.  Students will read exemplary theoretical texts from established and newer scholarly voices.  Topics vary and may include Marxism, Brecht, Artaud, theories fo the avant-garde, psychoanalysis, critical race theory, feminism, structuralism, post-structuralism, postmodernism, postcolonialism, and transnationalism.

THTR 212.title: Drama of Mixed Genres
THTR 212.description: Masterpieces of intermingled forms from Greeks to the present. Dramatists include Euripides, Shakespeare, Moliere, Pinter, and others.

THTR 213AAZZ.title: Histories of Theater, Dance, and Performance Studies
THTR 213AAZZ.description: Introduction to pre-1900 historical time periods in theater, dance, and performance studies. Students read exemplary historical texts and learn key historiographical methods from established and newer scholarly voices. Periods and topics vary and may include material conditions of performance, gender and sexuality studies, global theater and dance, and embodied and dramaturgical approaches to dance and theater history.

THTR 221.title: The History and Theory of Directing
THTR 221.description: Readings in the major theorists of directing and in the history of directing in the modern and contemporary theatre.

THTR 230.title: Dramatic Theory: Aristotle to Nietzsche
THTR 230.description: Detailed study of theories from The Poetics to The Birth of Tragedy.

THTR 232.title: Modern and Contemporary Theory
THTR 232.description: A graduate level introduction to twentieth and twenty-first century critical theory. Topics vary and may include Marxism, Brecht, Artaud, theories of the avant-garde, psychoanalysis, feminism, structuralism, post-structuralism, postmodernism, and postcolonialism.

THTR 250AAZZ.title: Topics in Dramatic Literature and Theatre History
THTR 250AAZZ.description: A survey course that introduces students to a range of historical periods, dramatic work, playwrights, artistic movements, and theatrical trends. Topics vary and may include classics in performance, translating drama, global theatre, violence in drama, dramatic genre, and literature and theatre.

THTR 251AAZZ.title: Special Topics in Performance Studies
THTR 251AAZZ.description: Varies in content from year to year, but offerings may include studies of the avant-garde and performance art, sport as ritual and performance, theatre on trial, politics and war as performance, embodiment, and global performance traditions.

THTR 252AAZZ.title: Critical Dance Studies: Special Topics in Dance History and Theory
THTR 252AAZZ.description: This graduate seminar provides an introduction to the history and critical theory of dance in  global contexts. The methodological focus may include critical dance studies, historiography,  ethnography, feminist theory, critical race theory, body theory - corporealities - art and architectural  (site-specific performance) theory, and performance studies. Students read and analyze a wide  array of critics, scholars, and artists and demonstrate fluency in critical dance studies through written  papers and weekly seminar discussion. Live Performance serves as archival source material.

THTR 254.title: Performance of Physicality
THTR 254.description: Explores various case studies of the theatrical representation and perception of the human body in Europe, the Americas, and Asia in the twentieth century especially related to the construction of gender, race, class, nation,  and sexuality.

THTR 255.title: Race, Immigration, and the Cold War Politics of Contemporary American Dance
THTR 255.description: An interdisciplinary graduate seminar that examines how racism, immigration, imagination, and geopolitics have shaped perceptions of the dancing body in both classical and contemporary dance. Dance Studies course that examines how racism in the United States has shaped and been shaped by the American stage. In an era of overt patriotism and nation-building, we study how the dancers and choreographers themselves contributed to the racialization bodies in motion.

THTR 256.title: Dancing the Diaspora: Tracing the Africanist Presence in   Afro-Caribbean and American Worlds
THTR 256.description: Traces a genealogy of dance and choreographic practice in the Afro-Caribbean and American worlds. Examination of a range of interdisciplinary texts, from theoretical discourses surrounding issues of race, blackness and collective, diasporic identity to dance histories of religious and concert stage traditions, to art historical texts that deepen our aesthetic understanding of dancing bodies in West African and Africanist religious ritual and secular performance.

THTR 261.title: Directing for Graduate Students
THTR 261.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.
THTR 261.description: An investigation of the fundamentals and techniques of directing, including principles of staging, text analysis, and actor coaching.

THTR 262.title: Practice in Design
THTR 262.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.
THTR 262.description: Projects and study in design; practical application to projects.

THTR 263.title: Practice in Dramaturgy
THTR 263.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.
THTR 263.description: Projects in dramaturgy; practical applications and projects.

THTR 264.title: Practice in Directing
THTR 264.prereq_description: Theater 221 or 261; graduate standing; consent of instructor.
THTR 264.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.
THTR 264.description: Advanced problems in directing, practical applications, and projects. Culminates in directing one-act plays.

THTR 265A.title: Practice in Playwriting
THTR 265A.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.
THTR 265A.description: An independent study in playwrighting. Students may work on a full-length play, a one act play, a solo performance text.

THTR 266.title: Practice in Theatre and Dance
THTR 266.description: Projects in various areas of theatre and dance, including acting, stage management, production and directing.

THTR 271A.title: Asian Theatre and Drama
THTR 271A.description: Dramatic literature and staged theater of Asia. Coverage varies from traditonal to contemporary dramatists and theatre styles from East Asia to India and/or Southeast Asia. Reception of Asian theatre in non-Asian contexts is often considered.

THTR 271B.title: Asian Performance Studies
THTR 271B.description: Performance modes examined in this course may include shaman ritual, puppetry, masked performance, religious ceremonies, mass movements, and political events from various regions of Asia and the Pacific. Performances are considered in their tourist and cross-cultural contexts as well as in terms of more conventional settings and aesthetics.

THTR 272.title: European Theatre and Drama
THTR 272.description: An examination of theatrical and dramatic traditions of Europe. Offerings vary, but may include ancient and medieval drama and theatre, the Renaissance, Shakespeare, as well as Enlightenment, Sturm and Drang and Romanticism, Realism, Naturalism, and Symbolism.

THTR 273A.title: Theater and Drama of the Americas
THTR 273A.description: An examination of pan-American trends and traditions in drama. Readings may range widely beyond national and continental borders to focus on specific countries and/or movements in Latin America, the United States, and Canada.

THTR 273C.title: Theatre and Drama of the United States
THTR 273C.description: An examination of trends and traditions in theatre of the United States. Roots of Broadway, U.S. Latino theatre, Asian American theatre, melodrama, the Group Theatre and its legacy, multicultural theatre and contemporary theater.

THTR 500.title: Teaching: Methods and Practice
THTR 500.prereq_description: Graduate standing and current appointment as a departmental teaching
THTR 500.comments: May be repeated for credit. Required of all teaching assistants. S/U grade.No unit credit allowed toward advanced degrees.
THTR 500.description: Introduction to the problems and techniques of teaching dramatic art, through teaching responsibilities in departmental courses and through consultation with supervising faculty members.

THTR 596.title: Directed Reading and Research
THTR 596.description: Individual tutorial. A written proposal for each tutorial must be approved by the department chair.

THTR 598.title: Master's Thesis Project, Research and Creative
THTR 598.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of eight units. No unit credit allowed toward advanced degrees.
THTR 598.description: Master's thesis project, research and creative.

THTR 599.title: Dissertation Research and Preparation
THTR 599.prereq_description: Consent of chair of student's doctoral committee. (Repeatable to 108 units - not 99).
THTR 599.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 108 units. S/U grading. No unit credit allowed toward advanced degree.

THTR W 2B.title: Performance in Global Contexts, Asia
THTR W 2B.description: This course surveys a range of Asian performances across a diversity of locations, from the  traditional theater forms of Japanese Kabuki, Indonesian Wayang Kulit, and Indian Kathakali to  modern forms in India and Japan to contemporary Chinese performance art. Theater forms like Chinese Jingju and Japanese Noh will prompt us to reevaluate what the performer does in rehearsal and in situations on and off the stage. By exploring recent modern and contemporary performance forms, we will reassess how an actor, dancer, or puppeteer can challenge the status quo and effect change. As we ask these questions, we will situate Asian performance within social, political, and historical contexts to understand its rich functions and significances.

THTR W 19.title: Design Fundamentals for Dance and Theater
THTR W 19.description: Lectures, demonstrations and projects to provide an understanding of the stage design process for theater and dance. Study of the elements, principles, terminology, and basic techniques. Exploration of the communicative and collaborative process between designer and choreographer/director. Concentration in scenic, costume, and lighting design.
